A moon is in circular orbit around a planet
Explain why the path of the moon is circular
Show that the mass \(M\) of the planet is given by the expression
where \(G\) is the gravitational constant
Use Fig. 1.2 and the expression in **(c)**(i) to show that the mass \(M\) of the planet is \(1.0 \times 10^{26} \text{kg}\)
Determine the speed of a moon in orbit around the planet with an orbital radius of \(1.2 \times 10^{8} \text{m}\)
Many moons are in circular orbit about a planet
The angular velocity of a moon is \(\omega\) when the orbit of the moon has a radius \(r\) about the planet
Fig. 1.2 shows the variation of \(r^3\) with \(1 / \omega^2\) for these moons
State the change in internal energy \(\Delta U\) for one complete cycle, XYZ
Calculate the amount \(n\) of gas
Complete Table 2.1
Use the space below for any working
The first law of thermodynamics for a system may be represented by the equation
State, with reference to the system, what is meant by:
\(\Delta U\) :
Explain how the first law of thermodynamics applies to the change Z to X
A fixed mass of an ideal gas has a volume \(V\) and a pressure \(p\)
The gas undergoes a cycle of changes, X to Y to Z to X, as shown in Fig. 2.1
Table 2.1 shows data for \(p\), \(V\) and temperature \(T\) for the gas at points X, Y and Z
State the names of the two forces acting on the block when it is stationary
The block is now displaced downwards as shown in Fig. 3.2 so that the surface of the water is higher up the block
State and explain the direction of the resultant force acting on the wooden block in this position
Explain why the oscillations of the block are simple harmonic
Show that the angular frequency \(\omega\) of the oscillations is given by
The block in **(b)** is now released so that it oscillates vertically
The resultant force \(F\) acting on the block is given by
where \(g\) is the gravitational field strength and \(x\) is the vertical displacement of the block from the equilibrium position
Explain why the maximum negative displacement of the block is not equal to its maximum positive displacement
The mass of the block is \(0.57 \text{kg}\)
Use Fig. 3.3 to determine the decrease \(\Delta E\) in energy of the oscillation for the first half oscillation

The block is now placed in a liquid with a greater density. The block is displaced and released so that it oscillates vertically. The variation with displacement \(x\) of the acceleration \(a\) of the block is measured for the first half oscillation, as shown in Fig. 3.3
Fig. 3.3
A small wooden block (cuboid) of mass \(m\) floats in water, as shown in Fig. 3.1
The top face of the block is horizontal and has area \(A\). The density of the water is \(\rho\)
State what is represented by an electric field line
The charge of P is \(+4.0 \text{nC}\) and the charge of Q is \(-7.2 \text{nC}\)
Determine the distance from P of the point on the line joining the two charges where the electric potential is zero
distance = .........m
State and explain, without calculation, whether the electric field strength is zero at the same point at which the electric potential is zero
An electron is positioned at point X, equidistant from both P and Q, as shown in Fig. 4.2
On Fig. 4.2, draw an arrow to represent the direction of the resultant force acting on the electron.
Two point charges P and Q are placed \(0.120 \text{m}\) apart as shown in Fig. 4.1
The switch is in position X so that the capacitor is fully charged
Calculate the energy \(E\) stored in the capacitor
Show that the time constant of the discharge circuit is 3.3 s
The fully charged capacitor in (a) stores energy \(E\)
Determine the time \(t\) taken for the stored energy to decrease from \(E\) to \(E / 9\)
The switch is now moved to position Y
A second identical capacitor is connected in parallel with the first capacitor
State and explain the change, if any, to the time constant of the discharge circuit
The variation with potential difference \(V\) of the charge \(Q\) on one of the plates of a capacitor is shown in Fig. 5.1
The capacitor is connected to an \(8.0\mathrm{V}\) power supply and two resistors R and S as shown in Fig. 5.2
The resistance of R is \(25\mathrm{k}\Omega\) and the resistance of S is \(220\mathrm{k}\Omega\)
The switch can be in either position X or position Y
Compare the magnetic flux in the two solenoids
Compare the magnetic flux linkage in the two solenoids
State Lenz's law of electromagnetic induction
The terminals of the smaller solenoid are connected together. The smaller solenoid is then removed from inside the larger solenoid
With reference to magnetic fields, explain why a force is needed to remove the smaller solenoid
A small solenoid of area of cross section \(1.6 \times 10^{- 3} \text{m}^2\) is placed inside a larger solenoid of area of cross-section \(6.4 \times 10^{- 3} \text{m}^2\), as shown in Fig. 6.1
The larger solenoid has 600 turns and is attached to a d.c. power supply to create a magnetic field
The smaller solenoid has 3000 turns
Complete the circuit in Fig. 7.1 by adding the necessary components in the gaps.
On Fig. 7.1 mark with a + the positive output terminal of the rectifier
Alternating current (a.c.) is converted into direct current (d.c.) using a full-wave rectification circuit. Part of the diagram of this circuit is shown in Fig. 7.1
Determine the equation for \(V\) in terms of \(t\), where \(V\) is in volts and \(t\) is in seconds
The supply is connected to a \(12\Omega\) resistor. Calculate the mean power dissipated in the resistor
mean power = .........W
The output voltage \(V\) of an a.c. power supply varies sinusoidally with time \(t\) as shown in Fig. 7.2
State the formula for the de Broglie wavelength \(\lambda\) of a moving particle
State the meaning of any other symbol used
State the name of the phenomenon shown by the electrons at the crystal
State what this phenomenon shows about the nature of electrons
Suggest why the thin crystal causes the phenomenon in (b)(i)
The electron is accelerated through a different potential difference. The new pattern observed on the screen is shown in Fig. 8.2
not to scale
State and explain the change that has been made to the potential difference to create the pattern shown in Fig. 8.2
Electrons accelerate through a potential difference, pass through a thin crystal and are then incident on a fluorescent screen
The pattern in Fig. 8.1 is observed on the fluorescent screen
not to scale
Complete the equation for this decay
Use Fig. 9.1 to determine the decay constant \(\lambda\) of polonium-211. Give a unit with your answer
Use your answer in **(b)**(i) to calculate the activity at time \(t = 0\) of the sample of polonium-211
activity = .........Bq
On Fig. 9.1, sketch a line to show the variation with \(t\) of the number of lead nuclei in the sample.
The variation with time \(t\) of the number of unstable nuclei \(N\) in a sample of polonium-211 is shown in Fig. 9.1
At time \(t = 0\), the sample contains only polonium-211
Calculate, in J, the total amount of energy given to alpha particles that are emitted between time \(t = 0.30 \text{s}\) and time \(t = 0.90 \text{s}\)
energy = .........J
Suggest why the total amount of energy released by the decay process between time \(t = 0.30 \text{s}\) and time \(t = 0.90 \text{s}\) is greater than your answer in **(c)**(i)
Each decay releases an alpha particle with energy \(6900\mathrm{keV}\)
Polonium-211 ( \(^{211}_{84}\mathrm{Po})\) decays by alpha emission to form a stable isotope of lead (Pb)
The X-ray tube produces an image using a current of 0.40A for a time of 20 ms
The specific heat capacity of tungsten is \(130 \text{J} \text{kg}^{-1} \text{K}^{-1}\)
Determine the temperature rise \(\Delta T\) of the tungsten target
The linear attenuation coefficient of the X-ray photons in muscle is \(0.22 \text{cm}^{-1}\)
Calculate the thickness \(t\) of muscle that will absorb \(80\%\) of the incident X-ray intensity
Table 10.1 shows the linear attenuation coefficient \(\mu\) for the X-ray photons in different tissues
Two X-ray images are taken, one of equal thicknesses of bone and muscle and another of equal thicknesses of blood and muscle
Explain why one of these images has good contrast, but the other does not
In an X-ray tube, electrons are accelerated through a potential difference of \(75\mathrm{kV}.\) The electrons then strike a tungsten target of effective mass \(15\mathrm{g}\)
The electron energy is converted into the energy of X-ray photons with an efficiency of \(5.0\%\). The rest of the energy is converted into thermal energy
PET scanning uses a tracer
Explain what is meant by a tracer
Explain what is meant by annihilation
State the names of the particles involved in the annihilation process
PET scanning involves annihilation
Calculate the total energy released in one annihilation event in **(b)**
energy = .........J
Calculate the wavelength of each gamma photon released
wavelength = .........m
Explain how the gamma photons are used to produce an image
Positron emission tomography (PET scanning) obtains diagnostic information from a person. The information is used to form an image
State what is meant by luminosity of a star
The luminosity of the Sun is \(3.83 \times 10^{26} \text{W}\). The distance between the Earth and the Sun is \(1.51 \times 10^{11} \text{m}\)
Calculate the radiant flux intensity \(F\) of the Sun at the Earth. Give a unit with your answer
Use data from (b) to calculate the mass that is converted into energy every second in the Sun
The radius of the Sun is \(6.96 \times 10^{8} \text{m}\)
Show that the temperature \(T\) of the surface of the Sun is \(5770 \text{K}\)
The wavelength \(\lambda_{\mathrm{max}}\) of light for which the maximum rate of emission occurs from the Sun is \(5.00 \times 10^{- 7} \text{m}\)
The temperature of the surface of the star Sirius is \(9940 \text{K}\)
Use information from (d) to determine the wavelength of light for which the maximum rate of emission occurs from Sirius
wavelength = .........m
